Seeing something like 96, 94, 98, 96, 98, 95 is normal, even in hospital settings. It's just the way our bodies work - a slight variation heart beat to heart beat. Circulatory issues play a role too. If your hands are cold, all pulse ox devices will have a hard time getting a reading. There isn't a lot of blood in a pale, freezing cold finger for it to get a reading from. Ditto that for especially low blood pressure. Or those with fingernail polish - it can't see thru the polish. And position - sometimes you have to reposition them a few times on the same finger, or use a different finger. And long nails push it too far back on your finger. It's the same drill regardless of home devices or hospital ones.This one seems reasonably accurate, for the little bit I have used it so far. It is good for learning what my baseline numbers are on most days, so if I get sick (get real..... When, not if, I'm not immune to every disease known to man) I can tell how far off things are. It shows a strong pulse wave form (meaning there is enough circulation in my finger for it to get a reading), and easy to read heart rate and oxygen status.For the very reasonable cost, it seems like a useful tool. "Your mileage may vary " If it helps prevent even one unnecessary trip to urgent care or the ER, it's worth it to me.
